measures.notes: Child care falities open only for childrens of parents working in crucial departments (doctors, police etc...)
Child care facilities open only for childrens of parents working in crucial departments (doctors, police etc...). Restriction valid until April 6th
Child care facilities open only for childrens of parents working in crucial departments (doctors, police etc...). Restriction valid until April 6th
Child care facilities open only for childrens of parents working in crucial departments (doctors, police etc...). Restriction extended until April 28th
Child care facilities open only for childrens of parents working in crucial departments (doctors, police etc...). Schools will be closed until after May holidays ending on May 3rd.

Child care facilities open only for childrens of parents working in crucial departments (doctors, police etc...). Schools will be closed until after May holidays ending on May 3rd.
On April 21st  the government communcate that Primary schools will open on May 11 but children will be attending in groups (i.e. not everyone present  all days), secondary schools will open on June 2nd.

Schools in primary education, including special (primary) education, day care and childminder care open their doors on May 11. Children can go to out-of-school care (BSO) on the days they go to school. Day care for children aged 0-4 and childminder care for children aged 0-12 opens regularly.
Children go to school 50% of the time. The time when the pupils are not in school is interpreted differently. That interpretation is determined by the school and the teachers.
Special (primary) education will open again 100%.
Schools in secondary (special) education will remain closed until at least 1 June. If necessary, schools are open for (school) exams. Secondary vocational education, colleges and universities are closed. Schools and universities provide distance education.
Schools in secondary (special) education will make preparations so that pupils can return to school (partly) from 2 June.

Schools in primary education, including special (primary) education, day care and childminder care open their doors on May 11. Children can go to out-of-school care (BSO) on the days they go to school. Day care for children aged 0-4 and childminder care for children aged 0-12 opens regularly.
Children go to school 50% of the time. The time when the pupils are not in school is interpreted differently. That interpretation is determined by the school and the teachers.
Special (primary) education will open again 100%.
Schools in secondary (special) education will remain closed until at least 1 June. If necessary, schools are open for (school) exams. Secondary education will restart as of June 1st, (the way in which it is further elaborated);
A plan is being made to open MBO further in due course and to open higher education again as of June 15 if the Virus stays under control (this is a forecast)

Schools in primary education, including special (primary) education, day care and childminder care open their doors on May 11. Children can go to out-of-school care (BSO) on the days they go to school. Day care for children aged 0-4 and childminder care for children aged 0-12 opens regularly.
Children go to school 50% of the time. The time when the pupils are not in school is interpreted differently. That interpretation is determined by the school and the teachers.
Primary education will reopen 100% on 8 June, unless current studies show that this is not justified.
Special (primary) education will open again 100%.
Schools in secondary (special) education will remain closed until at least 1 June. If necessary, schools are open for (school) exams. Secondary education will restart as of June 2nd.
Schools take measures so that 1.5 meters can be kept away. In practice, this means that not all pupils can be at school at the same time.  
Secondary special education will also open to all students on June 2. Here too schools take measures so that 1.5 meters can be kept away.
On 15 June, secondary vocational education and higher education (universities of applied sciences and universities) will again start with tests, exams, practical lessons and supervision of vulnerable students at the institution.

Schools in primary education, including special (primary) education, day care and childminder care open their doors on May 11. Children can go to out-of-school care (BSO) on the days they go to school. Day care for children aged 0-4 and childminder care for children aged 0-12 opens regularly.
Children go to school 50% of the time. The time when the pupils are not in school is interpreted differently. That interpretation is determined by the school and the teachers.
Primary education will reopen 100% on 8 June, unless current studies show that this is not justified.
Special (primary) education will open again 100%.
Schools in secondary (special) education will remain closed until at least 1 June. If necessary, schools are open for (school) exams. Secondary education will restart as of June 2nd.
Schools take measures so that 1.5 meters can be kept away. In practice, this means that not all pupils can be at school at the same time.  
Secondary special education will also open to all students on June 2. Here too schools take measures so that 1.5 meters can be kept away.
On 15 June, secondary vocational education and higher education (universities of applied sciences and universities) will again start with tests, exams, practical lessons and supervision of vulnerable students at the institution.

From 1 July, Pupils and teaching staff should always keep a distance of 1.5 meters. Pupils do not have to do that. This applies to all students within the school, regardless of their age. Students go to school on foot or by bicycle as much as possible. The protocols for schools are being adapted to the new situation. Secondary and secondary special education schools can open completely after the summer holidays.
Primary education is already fully open. The distance rule in primary schools is relaxed. Until now, teachers had to keep as far away as possible from students up to the age of 13. This is no longer necessary from 1 July.
Limitation only for people in quarantine and at risk.

Limitation only for people in quarantine and at risk. Nursing homes and small-scale housing in elderly care will be closed from March 20th for visitors and others who are not necessary for basic care.

Limitation only for people in quarantine and at risk. Nursing homes and small-scale housing in elderly care will be closed from March 20th for visitors and others who are not necessary for basic care.

From March 23 more restrictions applied: Stay at home as much as possible. Go outside for work only when you cannot work at home, for groceries, or to take care of others. You can get a breath of fresh air, but don't do this in a group. Always keep a distance from others (at least 1.5 meters) and avoid social activities and groups of people. Mayors can designate areas where group formation is prohibited. These can be parks, beaches or neighborhoods. In groups of 3 or more that do not keep a meter and a half away, maintenance is maintained.  Nursing homes and small-scale housing in elderly care will be closed from March 20th for visitors and others who are not necessary for basic care.

Nursing homes and small-scale housing in elderly care will be closed from March 20th for visitors and others who are not necessary for basic care.

From April 28th kids until 18 years old can re-stat doing sports with distance restrictions fro those older than 12 years.  From April 29, elderly people aged 70 years and older who live independently can be visited regularly by one or two permanent persons.

Still applies the rule to stay at home as much as possible. Go outside for work only when you cannot work at home. When outside keep the distance of 1,5m.
Sport: Children up to 12 years old can exercise, exercise and follow activities together under supervision. Young people from 13 to 18 years old are allowed to exercise outside with each other under supervision, but with a distance of 1.5 meters between them. Outdoor sports in groups are allowed for all ages from May 11, if 1.5 meters can be kept apart. No competitions, no shared changing rooms or showers.
Public transport: Only use public transport if you really need to, avoid rush hour and give each other space.
In train, bus and metro you are advised to wear non-medical masks. This is mandatory from 1 June.

Still applies the rule to stay at home as much as possible. Go outside for work only when you cannot work at home. When outside keep the distance of 1,5m.
Sport: Children up to 12 years old can exercise, exercise and follow activities together under supervision. Young people from 13 to 18 years old are allowed to exercise outside with each other under supervision, but with a distance of 1.5 meters between them. Outdoor sports in groups are allowed for all ages from May 11, if 1.5 meters can be kept apart. No competitions, no shared changing rooms or showers.
Public transport: Only use public transport if you really need to, avoid rush hour and give each other space.
In train, bus and metro you are advised to wear non-medical masks. This is mandatory from 1 June.
As of May 11 a first cautious step is being taken to relax the visiting arrangement for nursing homes.

Still applies the rule to stay at home as much as possible. Go outside for work only when you cannot work at home. When outside keep the distance of 1,5m.
Sport: Children up to 12 years old can exercise, exercise and follow activities together under supervision. Young people from 13 to 18 years old are allowed to exercise outside with each other under supervision, but with a distance of 1.5 meters between them. Outdoor sports in groups are allowed for all ages from May 11, if 1.5 meters can be kept apart. No competitions, no shared changing rooms or showers.
Public transport: Only use public transport if you really need to, avoid rush hour and give each other space.
As of May 11 a first cautious step is being taken to relax the visiting arrangement for nursing homes. 
From June 1st Public transport is only intended for necessary trips.
In the tram, (water) bus, metro and train, it is compulsory for travelers aged 13 years and older to wear a non-medical mask. This does not apply to stations, stops and platforms; there a mask is not mandatory. Everyone here keeps 1.5 meters away from others.
Travelers who do not wear a face mask after 1 June can be fined € 95.

Still applies the rule to stay at home as much as possible. Go outside for work only when you cannot work at home. When outside keep the distance of 1,5m.
Sport: Children up to 12 years old can exercise, exercise and follow activities together under supervision. Young people from 13 to 18 years old are allowed to exercise outside with each other under supervision, but with a distance of 1.5 meters between them. Outdoor sports in groups are allowed for all ages from May 11, if 1.5 meters can be kept apart. No competitions, no shared changing rooms or showers. From 1 June (organized and supervised by sports associations or professionals), young people aged 13 to 18 years old can exercise outside without 1.5 meters away. This relaxation already applied to children up to and including the age of 12. Sports competitions remain prohibited.
Public transport: Only use public transport if you really need to, avoid rush hour and give each other space.
As of May 11 a first cautious step is being taken to relax the visiting arrangement for nursing homes. 
From June 1st Public transport is only intended for necessary trips.
In the tram, (water) bus, metro and train, it is compulsory for travelers aged 13 years and older to wear a non-medical mask. This does not apply to stations, stops and platforms; there a mask is not mandatory. Everyone here keeps 1.5 meters away from others.
Travelers who do not wear a face mask after 1 June can be fined € 95.

From July 1st:
Inside and outside You always keep 1.5 meters away.
Rules in transport
You must always wear a face mask on public transport.
You always wear a mask in taxis, buses and coaches.
You must make a reservation.
And you will get a health check.
Are people from another household in your car?
Then all wear a mouth mask.
In all other transport you must keep a distance of 1.5 meters.
Like on a tour boat.

Exceptions to the 1.5 meter distance apply for children and young people:

People from 1 household do not have to keep a distance of 1.5 meters together.
Children up to the age of 12 do not have to keep 1.5 meters away from others.
Young people up to the age of 18 do not have to keep a distance of 1.5 meters.
They must keep a distance of 1.5 meters from adults.
In some situations it is difficult to keep 1.5 meters away.
Therefore, there are also exceptions for:

Persons in need of care and their supervisors.
Hairdressers, masseurs and instructors in teaching vehicles.
Athletes, actors and dancers.
People are recommended not to traver in high risk areas and unless they have sintoms they don't need to declare that they came back to NL from abroad.
People are strongly recommended not to travel abroad. Unless they have sintoms they don't need to declare that they came back to NL from abroad.
Only EU citizens and some other with specific requirements can enter NL from March 19, 6pm. This is valid for 30 days. details here in source 4.
Only EU citizens and some other with specific requirements can enter NL from March 19, 6pm. This is valid for 30 days.
Only EU citizens and some other with specific requirements can enter NL from March 19, 6pm. This is valid for 30 days.
Only EU citizens and some other with specific requirements can enter NL from March 19, 6pm. This is extended until April 28th.
Only EU citizens and some other with specific requirements can enter NL from March 19, 6pm. This is extended until May 15 2020. Details on exceptions are reported in source 1.

The Netherlands, together with all other Schengen countries and the United Kingdom, has closed its borders to people from outside Europe who do not make an essential trip. This entry ban applies until May 14.
All people flying from a high-risk area to the Netherlands must be able to show a health certificate. Only passengers with such a statement are allowed on board.
Everyone who flies to the Netherlands from a high-risk area is strongly advised to remain in home quarantine for 14 days after arrival.

The Netherlands, together with all other Schengen countries and the United Kingdom, has closed its borders to people from outside Europe who do not make an essential trip. This entry ban applies until May 14. As of May 15 no news about cancelling this restriction.
All people flying from a high-risk area to the Netherlands must be able to show a health certificate. Only passengers with such a statement are allowed on board.
Everyone who flies to the Netherlands from a high-risk area is strongly advised to remain in home quarantine for 14 days after arrival.

The Netherlands, together with all other Schengen countries and the United Kingdom, has closed its borders to people from outside Europe who do not make an essential trip. This entry ban applies until June 15. 
All people flying from a high-risk area to the Netherlands must be able to show a health certificate. Only passengers with such a statement are allowed on board.
Everyone who flies to the Netherlands from a high-risk area is strongly advised to remain in home quarantine for 14 days after arrival.

From June 15 traveling within Europe is possible with exclusion of UK, Sweden and Denmark. Some countries like France and Spain have not confirmed yet if they will allow Dutch people to enter their territory.
Traveling outside Europe is not recommended to limit the risks of a new outbreak. 
From June 15 tourists are allowed to travel to the Netherlands this summer. But only tourists from countries with about the same situation as in the Netherlands and must adhere to the Dutch rules.

From June 15 traveling within Europe is possible in the following countries: Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Estonia, France, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Poland, Portugal, the Czech Republic and Switzerland. Traveling outside Europe is not recommended to limit the risks of a new outbreak. 
From June 15 tourists are allowed to travel to the Netherlands this summer. But only tourists from countries with about the same situation as in the Netherlands and must adhere to the Dutch rules.
The Netherlands extends the border closure for people from outside Europe to July 1st, exceptions apply for specific cases.

From June 15 traveling within Europe is possible in the following countries: Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Estonia, France, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Poland, Portugal, the Czech Republic and Switzerland. Traveling outside Europe is not recommended to limit the risks of a new outbreak. 
From June 15 tourists are allowed to travel to the Netherlands this summer. But only tourists from countries with about the same situation as in the Netherlands and must adhere to the Dutch rules.

As of 1 July 2020, the Netherlands has lifted the travel ban for travelers who reside permanently in the following countries: Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay. For travelers from China, the entry ban will be lifted as soon as the country also allows EU citizens.
Exceptions apply for specific cases.

From June 15 traveling within Europe is possible in the following countries: Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Estonia, France, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Poland, Portugal, the Czech Republic and Switzerland. Traveling outside Europe is not recommended to limit the risks of a new outbreak. 
From June 15 tourists are allowed to travel to the Netherlands this summer. But only tourists from countries with about the same situation as in the Netherlands and must adhere to the Dutch rules.

As of 1 July 2020, the Netherlands has lifted the travel ban for travelers who reside permanently in the following countries: Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Montenegro, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Serbia, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay. For travelers from China, the entry ban will be lifted as soon as the country also allows EU citizens.
Exceptions apply for specific cases. 
The Netherlands has reintroduced the entry ban for Serbia and Montenegro on 8 July 2020.
Cancelled flights from China, Italy Iran, South Korea.
Cancelled flights from China, Italy Iran, South Korea. From march 17th all travel not strictly necessary are discouraged.

From June 15 traveling within Europe is possible in the following countries: Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Estonia, France, Iceland, Italy, Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Poland, Portugal, the Czech Republic and Switzerland. Traveling outside Europe is not recommended to limit the risks of a new outbreak.

Hairdressers, beauticians and others in so-called contact professions in the field of external care are unfortunately no longer allowed to practice their profession. For physiotherapists, for example, work as much as possible via video calling.

Hairdressers, beauticians and others in so-called contact professions in the field of external care are unfortunately no longer allowed to practice their profession. For physiotherapists, for example, work as much as possible via video calling.

Hairdressers, beauticians and others in so-called contact professions in the field of external care are unfortunately no longer allowed to practice their profession. For physiotherapists, for example, work as much as possible via video calling.

Hairdressers, beauticians and others in so-called contact professions in the field of external care are unfortunately no longer allowed to practice their profession. For physiotherapists, for example, work as much as possible via video calling.
All restaurants and cafes are currently closed up to and including May 20. Take-out or home delivery of food is allowed.

Shops take measures to ensure that people keep their distance, for example through a door policy and agreements on traveler behavior.
All food and beverage outlets are closed. Delivery and collection remain possible - also for coffee shops. Avoid crowds, keep 1.5 meters away and take your consumption with you.
Hotels are, only for hotel guests staying there, except for the closure of food and beverage outlets.

Also closed are: sports clubs, sports and fitness clubs, saunas, casinos, arcades, sex establishments. There is an exception for sports clubs when they allow outdoor sports or exercise for children and institutions for top sports.
It is forbidden to exercise contact professions, insofar as it is not possible to keep a distance of 1.5 meters from the customer. You can think of masseurs, hairdressers, nail stylists, escort services and driving instructors. Selling or delivering products is allowed, as long as the 1.5 meter distance can be guaranteed.
An exception is made for (para) medical professions when an individual medical indication exists. The healthcare provider must of course observe all necessary hygiene requirements.

Contact professions: Most contact professions are possible again. These are driving instructors, (para) medical professions (dietician, masseur, occupational therapist, dental prosthetician, etc.), employees in external care (hairdresser, beautician, pedicure, etc.) and alternative medicine (acupuncturist, homeopath, etc.). The work is organized as far as possible at a distance of one and a half meters.  We work by appointment, whereby the entrepreneur / employee and the customer discuss in advance whether the visit poses a risk.
Libraries: Libraries open their doors to the public again and take measures so that visitors can keep 1.5 meters away from each other.

From June 1st, if the virus is under control the following will apply:
Terraces with seats with a distance of 1.5 meters;
Cinemas, restaurants and cafes, and cultural institutions (such as concert halls and theaters) are allowed to open, subject to: 
a maximum of 30 persons (incl. staff) and 1.5 meters away;
visitors must make reservations;
in a conversation beforehand between entrepreneur and customer it is estimated whether a visit poses risks.
Museums and monuments are allowed to open if visitors buy tickets in advance, so that they can be steered within 1.5 meters.
Forecast as of July 1
If the virus remains under control, the communal toilets and showers at the campsites and holiday parks will reopen on 1 July. Also, the maximum number of visitors can hopefully be expanded to 100 people for cinemas, restaurants and cafes, cultural institutions. This also applies to organized meetings, such as church services, weddings and funerals.

General rule:

We keep 1.5 meters away from others.
Maximum 100 people per room with fixed seats (excluding staff).
No maximum number of people under the following conditions: fixed seats, reservation and health check in advance.
In shops, museums, libraries and other locations with flow of visitors, 1.5 meters away is the rule (locations themselves ensure compliance with this rule). There is no maximum number of people.
Events with more than 100 people are cancelled
From Mrach 23 All meetings are prohibited until June 1 (instead of April 6), even with fewer than 100 people.
From March 23 All meetings are prohibited until June 1 (instead of April 6), even with fewer than 100 people.
From March 23 All meetings are prohibited until June 1 (instead of April 6), even with fewer than 100 people. On April 21st the restriction was extended until September 1st.

All meetings are prohibited until May 19.
There are some exceptions:

Funerals and wedding ceremonies can continue if there is a maximum of 30 people together and 1.5 meters apart can be kept.
Religious and philosophical meetings preferably take place online; they can only physically pass if there are a maximum of 30 people together who always keep a distance of 1.5 meters.
Legally required meetings, such as council or shareholder meetings, can only take place if there are a maximum of 100 people who can keep 1.5 meters away.
Meetings necessary for the day-to-day operations of institutions, companies and other organizations may continue with a maximum of 100 people, and if 1.5 meters can be kept apart.
Organized and supervised outdoor sports and exercise for children and young people up to the age of 18 is allowed.

In principle, all events are prohibited until September 1.

This includes professional football matches, but also cultural events such as festivals, pop concerts and other musical performances.
Events are a specific category of gatherings. If the general ban on meetings would be relaxed in the future, it can be examined whether exemptions can be granted for certain performances. Cultural institutions will have to make a plan for this in which they apply the advice of RIVM on how this can be done safely.

In any case, cinemas, theaters, concert halls, libraries, museums and heritage with a public function will remain closed until 19 May.

There are some exceptions:

Funerals and wedding ceremonies can continue if there is a maximum of 30 people together and 1.5 meters apart can be kept.

Meetings necessary for the day-to-day operations of institutions, companies and other organizations may continue with a maximum of 100 people, and if 1.5 meters can be kept apart.
Organized and supervised outdoor sports and exercise for children and young people up to the age of 18 is allowed.

Cultural institutions will have to make a plan for this in which they apply the advice of RIVM on how this can be done safely.

From June 1st 30 people are allowed to meet in public buildings. People who work there don't count.

From July 1st:

Rules inside
You always keep 1.5 meters away.
In indoor spaces, a maximum of 100 people may gather.
Staff do not count.
More than 100 people are allowed.
But only if you reserve a place.
And you will get a health check.
This applies, for example, to cinemas, cafes, restaurants, theaters, weddings and funerals.
Discos and night clubs remain closed until September 1.
There will be rules for choirs.

Outside:
In outdoor areas, 250 people may gather.
Staff do not count.
More than 250 people are allowed in places with fixed seats.
You reserve a place.
And you will get a health check.
This applies, for example, to the catering industry.
There is no maximum number of people at zoos and amusement parks.
